ratings.comment: I would not take this class by choice but for a gened, it was a fine. Though accessible, he was very old fashioned, and every accommodation I had to bring my Mcburney advisor and 2 other people in to get. He will be retiring soon, but the lectures were ok and the midterm and final were 75% of the grade. There is some math.

Dave is a great guy who teaches a very interesting class! The midterm and final are worth 75% of your final grade total, but as long as you attend lectures and take good notes, you'll do well in the class. He doesn't post slides, so I would recommend attending every class.

Lecture heavy. I mean you might as well plan to attend every class. The midterm and final made or broke your grade. Plan to study concepts outside of class along side some math and a little economics. He is a great professor nonetheless, knows a lot of history and can apply a real-world situation to everything he is explaining. Use office hours

The class was very lecture heavy and had a lot of math concepts that were difficult to grasp. This was made even more difficult by the Prof. extreme difficulties navigating BBC. He often would draw incredibly confusing scribbles on the screen while try to explain things ultimately making the screen illegible. He seemednice but I wouldn't takeonline

The lectures were very hard to follow and he went off on tangents about his life experiences/irrelevant topics a lot, which was unfortunate since it was a lecture heavy class. This class also involved some math, which he hardly explained and got wrong a majority of the time. "Nice guy" but not a good/clear professor.
Expects one thing, grades you on another. Boring lectures. I guess you learn a thing or two, but nothing really significant.
very intelligent, but his lectures are extremely hard to follow. very sporadic with topics, and the book used that he wrote is just as difficult to understand.

A gargantuan mess of a course, taught without any awareness that the material is going at whirlwind speed and that the statistical notation differs enormously from that in the recommended readings.  Attempts to ask the class if they understand sound like veiled threats that you better understand and not hold up the lecture.
Dave's a super smart guy, and knows tons. However, public policy is not political science. Nothing wrong with public policy, it just ain't political science. Smart guy though.

I was really excited to take this class,  but the first half of the semester was not about poli sci-more of a health class. He's a really nice guy, but lectures are dry and the material is not what you would expect from a Poli Sci class. Also, the final exam is worth 50% of your grade, and not what you would expect to be on a cumulative final.

He expectated a lot of first semester freshmen.  We were thrown into writing policy papers and a 20 page research paper on health policy with littler prior knowledge of the subjects.  The work load was huge, but I did learn a lot in the process.  He seemed like a genuinely nice guy, but the class was a big stress.
Weimer is an all around good guy.  He's funny and makes dry subjects interesting.  He is generous with partial credit on exams.
